author: JB

review: After doing some research, I decided to purchase an Amazon Fire TV to replace our Blu-ray player as our streaming video player for our Amazon, Netflix and HBO accounts since it would no longer maintain internet connectivity and the it was deathly slow to begin with.Setting up the Fire TV could not be any easier, simply plug in the HDMI cable, connect power, either program your WiFi access or connect an ethernet cable and then turn it on.If you have a Prime account, the unit already comes preprogrammed for you, all you have to do after the initial new user video and search for updated firmware is to install any apps that you want to use with the FTV, you can even back out to select others while they are downloading.After setting up our FTV, we tried it out to compare against our other streaming units (1st gen Roku, Blu-ray players & Hopper) since one of our biggest problems has been with buffering while watching our programs unless we allow adequate time for them to be fully downloaded to the device (only Hopper).We selected a show to watch immediately both from Amazon's library and from Netflix, in both cases we had absolutely zero buffering!!Combine that with the highly responsive controls (no lag time or waiting for the device to catch up) and the relatively easy to navigate menus, we have found the a streaming video player that we absolutely love!The only legitimate complaint that I have about using the FTV (which was voiced by other users) is Amazon's choice to not clearly label what programs are free for Prime subscribers (come on Amazon, how hard is it to program the software to identify and tell us what is free?).For those of you who complain about the lack of an HDMI cable, get over it since very few if any products ever come with one (or at least one you actually want to use or is the right length). Amazon offers their own house brand of cables which I have found to be excellent, offer a wide range of lengths and are priced very well for their quality. In my case, this allowed me to order a 3' cable rather than having to deal with a 5' or 6' cable and was only $5 (figure it was a fair trade since my FTV was only $79).We are normally an all Apple household, but being that the Apple TV is far more limited in third party apps that it supports compared to competing products as well as having less memory and processing power, the Fire TV earned our choice to be our streaming video player.As soon as the Fire TV Stick becomes available, will consider purchasing one for our bedroom TV since it has an unused USB port that the power cable can be connected to eliminating the need for a larger power strip.Now if Amazon would package both Fire TV units with a prepaid Prime membership card (priced at say $150 & $89 respectively), this would make an excellent gift for friends and family.
